Utterance: Hi again! It’s nice to see you. How have things been since our last meeting?
Hey! Things have been pretty good. We’ve had some good talks at home.
That’s wonderful to hear! Have you been able to implement any of the discipline strategies we discussed?
Yes, we started to set clear expectations with our daughter about her schoolwork. It’s been a bit of a challenge, but we’re working on it.
That’s a great start! How has she responded to the new expectations?
She seems to understand better. There are still moments of resistance, but overall, she’s adapting.
That’s a positive sign. How do you feel when she pushes back against the expectations?
Honestly, it frustrates me. I want her to understand the importance of school.
It’s understandable to feel that way. When you feel frustrated, what do you think would help you manage those emotions?
I think taking a step back and reminding myself that she’s still learning would help.
That’s a great insight. Practicing patience can be tough, especially when you care deeply. Have you been able to practice any of the coping strategies we talked about?
A little bit. I tried to take deep breaths when I felt overwhelmed.
That’s a good strategy! How did it work for you in those moments?
It helped me calm down before responding. I was able to approach her more positively.
That’s fantastic! It sounds like you’re building a toolkit for managing your emotions. What other strategies do you think might be helpful?
I think talking things out with my girlfriend when I’m feeling frustrated could help too.
Absolutely! Open communication with your partner can create a united front and support system. Have you had the chance to talk about your feelings with her?
Yes, we had a good discussion about how to handle our daughter’s resistance together.
That’s excellent! It’s great to hear you’re both on the same page. How did that conversation go?
It felt really productive. We both shared our concerns and agreed to support each other more.
That’s what teamwork is all about! Have there been any moments recently when you felt proud of how you handled a situation with your daughter?
Yeah, there was a time she got upset about a grade, and instead of getting frustrated, I talked her through it calmly.
That’s a significant achievement! How did she respond to your calm approach?
She calmed down and was able to express her feelings. We ended up having a really good conversation.
That’s wonderful! It sounds like you’re fostering an environment where she feels safe to express herself. What do you think you can do to continue building that environment?
I think I need to keep encouraging her to share her feelings and reassure her that it’s okay to make mistakes.
That’s a great plan. Encouragement and reassurance can help her feel more secure. Have you thought about how to celebrate her successes, no matter how small?
I haven’t really, but I think celebrating her achievements would motivate her more.
Absolutely! Celebrating successes can boost her confidence. What are some ways you could celebrate her accomplishments?
Maybe we could have a little treat or go out for ice cream when she does well on a test.
That sounds like a fun idea! It can create positive associations with her efforts. How do you feel about incorporating that into your routine?
I think it would be great! It would give her something to look forward to.
That’s a wonderful perspective. It sounds like you’re making great strides in your parenting journey. Is there anything else you’d like to explore in our next session?
I’d like to discuss how to handle conflicts better with my girlfriend, too.
That’s a valuable topic! We can work on communication strategies for conflict resolution. How does that sound?
Perfect, I’m looking forward to it.
Me too! Keep up the great work, and I’ll see you next time.
Thanks, Ellie. Bye!
